results.title: A Matter of choice
results.creator_credit: Tetra Media Productions, ONF | NFB, Jason Paikowsky and Allan Goldstein
results.brief_description: Nuclear power is the subject of this film that opens with a tour of the Bruce Nuclear Power Plant located on Lake Huron near Port Elgin. Questions regarding safety, cost and decision-making powers are raised by various people in the area. In view of Ontario Hydro’s plans to complete by 1983 the construction of several plants at a projected cost of $22 million, this film examines a timely and controversial issue. Interviewer: Howard Hutton. Narrator: Christine Johnston.

results.title: A Matter of Chance Episode 2
results.brief_description: One of a series which looks at the problems and aspirations of the disabled. Anne Deveson looks at three different teaching methods which are having enormous success with intellectually handicapped youngsters. Until recently some of these children could do nothing for themselves: they are deaf, blind and mute and can only communicate by touch. Yet now they can dress, wash and feed themselves and, according to their teacher, “The sky’s the limit”

results.title: A Matter of care: a review of the work of the Repatriation Department
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Frank Bagnall and Cecil Holmes
results.brief_description: Examines the work being done by the Department of repatriation. In the hospitals the effect of the Department’s activities can be seen in terms of the actual people who receive assistance and care. Also shows the social workers helping with problems of adjustment and therapy and training classes aimed at creating new interest in life. Script and direction by Cecil Holmes.

results.title: A Matter of attitudes
results.brief_description: Patrick Watson and Laurier Lapierre undertake a survey of the extent of water and air pollution in Canada. What they discover provides abundant evidence of our prodigal abuse of precious natural resources. That action is necessary, everyone in the film agrees, but there is less accord as to whether responsibility rests with industry, government, or municipality.
